article.headline: Texas A&M 74, Baylor 62
article.story: COLLEGE STATION, Texas (AP) -- Texas A&M coach Billy Gillispie prodded Acie Law to be more aggressive in Saturday's game. It paid off. Law scored 11 points, had two rebounds and a steal in the game's final 6½ minutes to help the Aggies to a 74-62 win over Baylor. Law finished with 22 points, including two 3-pointers, five rebounds and five assists. But even after such a gamebreaking performance, Gillispie wants more from his sophomore star. "Acie wasn't as aggressive as he could be," Gillispie said. "He picked his spots and made a lot of big plays but I'd like to see him be more aggressive more consistently." For his part, Law, who added nine points in the final 3:50, said he did listen to what his coach was saying but it simply came down seizing opportunities. "The last few minutes of the game I saw some chances to break down the defense and I took advantage of it," he said. "It wasn't about me taking over though. It was a team effort." "Everybody just stepped up and played well and created open looks there at the end." Freshman Joseph Jones added 21 points to help the Aggies (14-4, 3-4 Big 12) to their school-record 13th home win this season. Texas A&M led 53-51 with 6:53 remaining before going on a 10-0 run, which began with a layup by Law and was highlighted by Jones' one-handed put-back dunk with just more than five minutes left. The shot gave Texas A&M a 59-51 lead and brought the raucous crowd of 10,818 to its feet. "I credit them down the stretch for making big plays and credit their crowd as much as I do the team," said Baylor coach Scott Drew. Jones was a perfect 5-for-5 from the free throw line and also had 13 rebounds for his sixth double-double of the season. "I thought Joe was outstanding," Gillispie said. "He was a force down low the entire game, but especially in the second half." Jones, who had averaged just more than seven points in the last three games, constantly got the best of Baylor's Tommy Swanson. "The guy they had was real tall but he wasn't that strong or physical," Jones said. "It was a good break." Baylor (9-8, 1-5) was led by Aaron Bruce who scored 27 points, including four 3-pointers. The Bears kept it close in the first half almost solely because of their 3-point shooting. They were 7-of-11 for 64 percent shooting in the opening period. Baylor has now lost three straight and four of its last five games. Texas A&M led by one at halftime and opened the second half with an 8-0 run to extend its lead to 44-35. Baylor relied on their long-range shooting again to cut the lead to 46-43 about midway through the second half. The Bears hit 11 shots from beyond the arc, with Kevis Shipman joining Bruce with four 3-pointers. Texas A&M increased its lead to 51-46 when the Bears threatened again. The Aggies led early, outscoring the Bears 7-0 in the games' first two minutes. Baylor did not lead until Patrick Fields hit a free throw with 2:52 left in the first half to give the Bears a 30-29 edge. Bobby Leach had a career-high 14 points and Antoine Wright had 11 points and 11 rebounds for Texas A&M.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
